headline: The Lead with Jake Tapper
subHeadline: Governors Whitmer And Shapiro Campaigning For Vice President Harris; Republicans Attacks Harris On Immigration Record; President Biden Commemorates 60th Anniversary Of The Civil Rights Act; Biden Calls For Major U.S. Supreme Court Reforms; Protests Erupt Across Caracas After Maduro Claims Reelection. Aired 5-6p ET

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: -- see the data in Venezuela, where strongman leader Nicolas Maduro claims he won, but so is his political opponent.Plus, the new heightened sense of a wider war in the Middle East as the world waits to see how Israel will respond to the attack that killed 12 children in the northern Israel Golan Heights region. What stance is the U.S. taking? Biden's National Security Advisor John Kirby will be here. And leading this hour with only 175 days left in his term, President Biden is rolling out bold new proposals for the U.S. Supreme Court calling for term limits for justices, which would need the approval of Congress. He wants to strip legal immunity for future presidents, which would require constitutional changes. Biden's vice president, Kamala Harris, has endorsed these reforms as her own presidential campaign takes hold. This hour, as Biden gets ready to speak in Texas, two Democratic governors, Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan and Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, will campaign in support (inaudible). And in just a few minutes here on "The Lead," I'm going to talk to the governor of New Mexico, Democrat Michelle Lujan Grisham, as Harris faces an uproar of Republican criticism in her border state. But first, Biden's court reform plan. CNN's Kayla Tausche is at the White House. Kayla, the prospect of Congress passing these reforms is pretty much nil. How much of this is really just about rallying the Democratic base?

utterances.speaker: KAYLA TAUSCHE, CNN SENIOR WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Jake, that's certainly a big element of this, especially considering that President Biden first alluded to the timing of these reforms on a call with progressive lawmakers when he was trying to shore up support for his own candidacy and said that he was going to be rolling out some of these Supreme Court reforms, that he was going to need those lawmakers help in advancing some of these proposals.But, of course, that's nearly an impossible task. House Speaker Mike Johnson today calling those proposals dead on arrival. The White House's director of public engagement saying that they were going to give it the good old team try, but that they understood that there were going to be immense challenges awaiting some of those proposals, which include 18-year term limits for justices, a code of ethics that would apply to justices, as well as a constitutional amendment removing presidential immunity. That's something that would require the involvement of states as well, which makes it an even more Herculean task than before. It's also worth noting, Jake, that this is about legacy for President Biden. He began his administration by appointing a bipartisan commission on the Supreme Court. That commission produced a nearly 300-page report at the end of his first year in office that's been sitting on the shelf. And they did very detailed studies on things like term limits and an ethics code for those justices. So the president certainly had a lot of material to draw from in making this decision. And we've also now been told that Vice President Harris was deeply involved in deciding how and what to propose today, however unrealistic it may be, Jake.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And, Kayla, Vice President Harris is going to return to the campaign trail tomorrow morning after announcing a staggering fundraising haul. What's on her schedule?

utterances.speaker: TAUSCHE
utterances.sentences: Well, we know that she'll be delivering a rally in Georgia the second in two weeks that we are expecting to be a very high energy affair, much like her first campaign rally in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, was last week. What's notable about her return to Georgia after going to Battleground Wisconsin last week, is that it's a state that really became out of grasp for Democrats when Biden was the candidate.Now Harris is making a renewed push. There's a belief within the campaign and within the party that Georgia could be in play again and that Harris could be the one to deliver it again. And so that's why that visit is being watched very closely tomorrow morning, Jake.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about the race for president. You say that you've seen some renewed energy among Hispanic voters now that Vice President Harris is the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee. We have seen a swing in national polling among Hispanic voters. Biden -- when Biden was the nominee or the presumptive nominee, he was trailing Trump with Hispanic voters, 50 percent to 41 percent. Those same voters now split about evenly, 47 percent for Harris, 45 percent for Trump.So, yes, she's doing better, but I think Joe Biden won 65 percent of the Latino vote in 2020. She's still far behind where she needs to be in order to win, no?

utterances.speaker: GRISHAM
utterances.sentences: Well, I think one thing that we haven't quite assessed yet is that we got a whole bunch of first-time voters may not be anywhere in the polling radar. Hispanics are the youngest voters in America. We've got 66 percent of the Hispanic voters eligible in New Mexico who are going to be first time voters, 45 percent highest per capita in the nation. Hispanic voters (inaudible) I am seeing on the ground, incredible enthusiasm by young people. And how do you (inaudible) -- they're volunteering.They want to be part of strategy calls. They're interested in learning more about the candidate. They're coming to the Democratic Party. They're coming to any of the unofficial events that I'm hosting as governor. It is a sea change in attitudinal right shift, which I think bodes very well for Hispanic voters and their turnout for the vice president.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You're a border state governor. Just yesterday, you called on the Biden administration to do more when it comes to border resources and agents. When Vice President Harris was running for president in 2019 as a senator, she said she thought crossing the border without document -- documentation should be a civil offense and it should be decriminalized. Do you want her to tack more to the center on these border issues than she -- then where she was when she was running for president in 2019?

utterances.speaker: GRISHAM
utterances.sentences: You know, honestly, Jake, as a border state governor and someone who understands these issues and these pressures and frustrations, I don't want any more political labels and I don't want any more politicking about the border. We know that we have people who are desperate to seek asylum and refugee status. We need a fair, safe process for doing that. You need to be able to get visas up front.We need more economic opportunity for the countries that create in the triangle this kind of mass migration. But we also need security at the border. We've got to use new technology and tools. We don't invest in border agents or ICE. We're not smart about our ports of entry. We've just sort of languished in this political design. And it is for me despicable that the former president and Republicans continue to politicize this and weaponize these issues at the border. It harms our commercial activity, our economic activity, our public safety, our ability to work across the border with Mexico to make sure we're all safer. I'm sure you saw two huge arrests related to the cartel happened actually in New Mexico in the El Paso sector. So I don't want anyone anywhere politically except pass comprehensive immigration reform. This is a candidate who believes in that, who stood up for that. And in the meantime, the Biden-Harris administration have provided relief to states like New Mexico by getting agents where we need them most.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Okay. I want to ask you another question because you've had very kind words to say about Arizona Senator Mark Kelly from neighboring Arizona as a possible Kamala Harris choice for vice president. You haven't yet officially endorsed him for that job. Why not?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Given the Republicans continually attack --

utterances.speaker: GRISHAM
utterances.sentences: But I'm not Mark Kelly. Who doesn't want (inaudible) with them?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Given that the Republicans continually attack the Biden administration over the border and immigration and it is consistently where voters give the Biden Harris administration the lowest marks, do you think it would help Vice President Harris to pick a running mate from a border state?

utterances.speaker: GRISHAM
utterances.sentences: Listen, I don't -- that's going to hurt in any way. And I think people do want a productive set of responses. But again, and I really appreciate your focus here, Jake, we need to be talking not about responding to Republicans alleging chaos. I mean, we've got the lowest border crossings since the Trump administration, down by 55 percent.We're doing the right work in this administration. But it's easy to change perception, demonizing immigrants, having really heinous. Frankly, it's pure evil the way in which they talk about minorities and immigrants in this country. And so to divide the country, to stoke fear and hate as opposed to that we're doing the right work. But it will never be enough until Congress stops weaponizing border issues. Meantime, states like mine, we understand. I understand smart border security. I worked on the USA Act with Senator McCain and Will Hurd from Texas and Congressman Aguilar. We had a really good package. Probably Trump wasn't going to sign it. We know the damage to attacking Dreamers and their parents. We've got so many mixed status families. Half of the children in California have an immigrant parent. I mean, this makes no sense to be demonizing. I think let's solve problems.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GRISHAM
utterances.sentences: We know we can. We need to think we can do that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Governor, thank you so -- thank you so much. President Biden is stepping out right now to speak marking the 60th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act. Let's listen in.(BEGIN LIVE VIDEO)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And we're back with our politics lead and 2024 lead. We just heard from President Biden calling for new proposals to reform the United States Supreme Court including proposing 18-year term limits the panel is here to discuss. Kendra, let me start with you. President Biden calling for term limitsfor justices which would need obviously the approval of Congress. The Speaker has said it's dead on arrival not going to happen. Vice President Harris who's running for president also endorsed all of this, how much do you think she's actually going to talk about these proposals on the stump running for president?

utterances.speaker: KENDRA BARKOFF LAMY, FORMER PRESS SECRETARY FOR VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I think it'll be a part of it. But I think she's going to continue her main message that she's been talking about, which is access to health care for women, you know, her record, being a prosecutor. But look, I think today's speech for him was partially about his legacy and what he wants, you know, for people to remember him by in the future.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And we heard him I assume a lot of those remarks towards the end, we're not in his prepared speech, riffing about his beginning and politics, kind of like homespun, folksy kind of stuff. I imagine we're going to hear a lot of that between now and January.

utterances.speaker: ANNIE LINSKEY, REPORTER, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that's right. I mean, I feel like we really just listened to two speeches. You know, he even sort of did the wind down on the teleprompter speech, and then kind of launched into how he got into politics, his early -- his kind of first moments when people were trying to convince him to run for Senate.And that part of the speech just felt so much different to me that he was sort of reminiscing, he's with a really friendly audience. He has just gone through a really very difficult period, and he was sick on top of that. And so I just think you're seeing like the second part of that speech was just the more relaxed Joe Biden that we're in part of the beginning of a goodbye tour, which I think will be about a six month goodbye tour.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, let's look forward now to the 2024 race because, Marc, Illinois Governor JB Pritzker, Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro, reportedly in the running to be the running mate for vice president Harris. They're both today blasting Iowa's abortion law which took effect today. I think it's a six-week ban.Shapiro said quote, another abortion ban brought to you by Donald Trump, we cannot let him back in the White House. We must restore every women's freedom to choose. Do you think this issue is going to hurt Republicans come November?

utterances.speaker: MARC LOTTER, CHIEF COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER, AMERICA FIRST POLICY INSTITUTE
utterances.sentences: Ultimately no, because I think it's what democracy is about. I mean, this is not brought to you by Donald Trump is brought to you by the state legislature, the elected representatives of the people of Iowa, the governor of Iowa who signed it into law and Donald Trump has said that there -- when there are states that do some laws, he thought that might have been a little too far. He's -- there'll be others that go too far the other way and I think that's how democracy works that. You've got to bring find a middle ground and I think we'll see all kinds of experiments to do that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Kendra go.

utterances.speaker: TAPER
utterances.sentences: What do you think? Obviously it's going to be a big part of the of the Harris campaign. But let's talk about beefsteaks for one second.

utterances.speaker: LINSKEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. OK.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Because we're just talking about Shapiro and Pritzker. Obviously, we've talked about Kelly. We've talked about others on the show. What is your reporting indicator as to as to who is the finalists? Do you think?

utterances.speaker: LINSKEY
utterances.sentences: Well, right now, I think Harris is in this sort of magical position where all of these people who are many of them and key swing states are running in front of television cameras, and putting out their very best foot forward to audition for this role.And for her, it's fantastic. You have all of these built in surrogates who have every incentive to come up with the most sparkling things to say that make her look good and make her campaign look good. You already saw Tim Walz some of his comments about Trump being weird, had been adopted by the campaign. So they clearly really liked that talking point. But you know, you're -- she's not having to do any work to get these folks out there talking about her and saying good things about her. So I think, you know, if you're Kamala Harris, it's just kind of fabulous moment, but who is it ultimately going to be? I mean, I have my own little theories, but I think my sense is they don't haven't come up with person yet.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Before we go, Marc, I have to ask you on Saturday, Donald Trump spoke at the Bitcoin convention, praising Bitcoin, he said, those who say that Bitcoin is a threat to the dollar have the story exactly backwards. I believe it is exactly backwards. Bitcoin is not threatening the dollar. The behavior of the current U.S. government is really threatening the dollar. He said the exact opposite in 2021. He said this.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DONALD TRUMP, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: Those who say that Bitcoin is a threat to the dollar have the story exactly backwards. I believe it is exactly backwards. Bitcoin is not threatening the dollar. The behavior of the current U.S. government is really threatening the dollar. A Bitcoin, I just seems like a scam. I don't like it because it's another currency competing against the dollar. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So that's obviously what he said at the Bitcoin Conference. And then he said, it seems like a scam. This isn't 2021. Like it's another currency competing against the dollar. What do you make of this reversal?

utterances.speaker: LOTTER
utterances.sentences: I think as we've seen this technology evolve. And we've seen this market kind of develop, he realizes that if we don't take leadership on it, China will. And I think he's tried to put America in a position where if there is going to be this kind of currency, it's going to be us. That is the leader on it and not trailing falling behind and letting our adversaries do it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Kendra, before we go, who's your favorite in the beefsteaks?

utterances.speaker: LAMY
utterances.sentences: I'm going to go with Cooper.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Cooper, Roy Cooper of North Carolina.

utterances.speaker: LAMY
utterances.sentences: Yes. North Carolina.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You just like his style or former rocketeer (ph) or?

utterances.speaker: LAMY
utterances.sentences: I think, you know, I think that there's a much condensed, you know, race for her. I think she's going to go with someone she knows and trusts. I have no inside knowledge, obviously. But they work together when she was an AG and he was an AG and I think I don't know, it's just a random guess.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Our world lead today people are taking to the streets of Venezuela to protest the announced results of Sunday's presidential election. Strongman Nicolas Maduro claimed a victory in what the United States and other democracies see as a very sketchy questionable elections.Still, Venezuelan voters turned out in droves, many warning they would leave the country if Maduro won, that would add to roughly 8 million Venezuelans who have already fled Venezuela under its two-term rule, setting fears of worsening violent, repression and economic collapse under another Maduro administration. Let's get right to CNN En Espanol is Alejandra Oraa in Venezuela's capital and Alejandra, the protests are heating up. But what's happening right now where you are?

utterances.speaker: ALEJANDRA ORAA, CNN EN ESPANOL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Hi, Jake, I am in Caracas, Venezuela. And actually things are very -- are getting very tense at the moment. I don't know if you're able to hear the sound around me. But at this time, we see a lot of people on the streets requesting transparency on the results.And what's interesting that's happening here. We saw, for example, on different points of Venezuela statues being pushed over, a perfect example was a statue of Hugo Chavez that was pushed over in another city of Venezuela. And the people that got out of the streets, they say two things. Number one, that they want an audit of the election results because they don't believe on the result that the CME, the institution in charge of counting the ballots gave at midnight today. They gave a victory to Nicolas Maduro 34.2 percent. But they also request something that's very important. They want transparency. They want their votes to be counted. They want to audit, but they also say no candidate has asked us to go to the streets, meaning Nicolas Maduro, Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia. We're not able to see how many people are on the streets today. But what's interesting is, is that most people that are on the streets are actually requesting transparency. So they are for the opposition candidate that didn't win yesterday, which is Edmundo Gonzales Urritia.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Alejandra Oraa, thank you so much. Appreciate it. I want to bring in the White House National Security communications adviser retired Rear Admiral John Kirby now. Admiral Kirby, what are the reasons that the U.S. is skeptical of these election results and what will the U.S. do if proof emerges that shows Maduro actually did not win?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So a deal last year brokered by the Biden administration promised sanction relief on Venezuela's oil and gas sector if Maduro promised to hold free and fair elections. The U.S. reactivated the sanctions in April, when it became clear to us officials that Maduro was not holding up his part of the deal.What ultimately convinced President Biden back in 2023 that Maduro would stick to his word?

utterances.speaker: KIRBY
utterances.sentences: Well, it wasn't about whether he would or wouldn't stick to his word. It was a result of diplomatic conversations that we had with Maduro and his team that led us to believe that a he was making these declarations, and at least what appeared to be good faith.We wanted to also negotiate in good faith as well. And so we were open to easing some of the sanctions on him. We did see some positive movements by the Maduro regime in those early months. But again, they backtracked on it, persecuting opposition authorities, shutting them down, arresting them. And so the sanctions came back on again, as for what will happen next, we're going to reserve our judgment, until we can get a much clearer sense of the of the data itself.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Let's turn to the Middle East, a rocket fired by the terrorist group Hezbollah in Lebanon, killed 12 Druze children playing soccer in the Golan Heights section of Israel, you say the fears of an additional war between Israel and Hezbollah are exaggerated. Why are they exaggerated?

utterances.speaker: KIRBY
utterances.sentences: We believe based on the conversations that we've been having with our counterparts that there doesn't -- that doesn't appear to be the likely and the most imminent outcome right now. And look, I'm not going to sound pollyannish. Obviously, we've been concerned about the tensions along that blue line, the border between Israel and Lebanon for quite some time, and we've been working diplomatically to try to ease those tensions. We still believe there's time and space for those diplomatic conversations to occur.Now that said, Jake, as I also made clear today, Israel has a right to defend itself. It should not have, the people of Israel should not have to live under the threat of these kinds of rocket and missile attacks such as they've been coming under from Hezbollah. Now the (INAUDIBLE) have said they're going to respond. I'll let them speak to that. And I'll let them talk to their operations. We're going to make sure that they have what they need to defend themselves.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I'm wondering what the latest on the ceasefire and hostage release deal is, it seems like the Biden administration has in the past said things along the lines of the balls in Hamas' court. But maybe you're not saying it so much these days, because the ball is in Netanyahu's court, even people in Netanyahu's own government are saying he's holding up the deal. What is the status of the ceasefire hostage release deal and who is ultimately holding it up?

utterances.speaker: KIRBY
utterances.sentences: The teams are back at it. As I think, you know, negotiations are back on to try to close these gaps. We believe, as we said before, that those gaps are narrow enough that they can be closed. There's some details that need to be implemented. I don't want to negotiate here in public.What's going to be required, Jake, no kidding, is compromising leadership on both sides. They've got to try to come together and get this ceasefire deal in place. We believe it's a good deal. We believe both sides should accept it. We believe we need to move forward and get those hostages home with their families.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What's your message to the hostage family says you know, five of those families are American -- joint American-Israeli citizens, five of the hostages who are alive. There are eight Americans total but five of them have American citizenship.

utterances.speaker: KIRBY
utterances.sentences: That's right. We want them to know that President Biden as he told them last week remains 110 percent committed to getting their loved ones home, to getting all the hostages released, to getting a ceasefire in place. And even as we speak, the United States is involved in these negotiations. We're not going to shirk our responsibility. We're going to keep our shoulders to the wheel. We're going to get them home.
